paragraphs: October 2023One of the most important things I didn't understand about the world when I was a child is the degree to which the returns for performance are superlinear.Teachers and coaches implicitly told us the returns were linear.

"You get out," I heard a thousand times, "what you put in." They meant well, but this is rarely true. If your product is only half as good as your competitor's, you don't get half as many customers. You get no customers, and you go out of business.It's obviously true that the returns for performance are superlinear in business.

Some think this is a flaw of capitalism, and that if we changed the rules it would stop being true. But superlinear returns for performance are a feature of the world, not an artifact of rules we've invented.

We see the same pattern in fame, power, military victories, knowledge, and even benefit to humanity. In all of these, the rich get richer. [1]You can't understand the world without understanding the concept of superlinear returns.

And if you're ambitious you definitely should, because this will be the wave you surf on.It may seem as if there are a lot of different situations with superlinear returns, but as far as I can tell they reduce to two fundamental causes: exponential growth and thresholds.The most obvious case of superlinear returns is when you're working on something that grows exponentially.

For example, growing bacterial cultures. When they grow at all, they grow exponentially. But they're tricky to grow. Which means the difference in outcome between someone who's adept at it and someone who's not is very great.Startups can also grow exponentially, and we see the same pattern there.

Some manage to achieve high growth rates. Most don't. And as a result you get qualitatively different outcomes: the companies with high growth rates tend to become immensely valuable, while the ones with lower growth rates may not even survive.Y Combinator encourages founders to focus on growth rate rather than absolute numbers.

It prevents them from being discouraged early on, when the absolute numbers are still low. It also helps them decide what to focus on: you can use growth rate as a compass to tell you how to evolve the company.

But the main advantage is that by focusing on growth rate you tend to get something that grows exponentially.YC doesn't explicitly tell founders that with growth rate "you get out what you put in," but it's not far from the truth.

And if growth rate were proportional to performance, then the reward for performance p over time t would be proportional to pt.Even after decades of thinking about this, I find that sentence startling.Whenever how well you do depends on how well you've done, you'll get exponential growth.

But neither our DNA nor our customs prepare us for it. No one finds exponential growth natural; every child is surprised, the first time they hear it, by the story of the man who asks the king for a single grain of rice the first day and double the amount each successive day.What we don't understand naturally we develop customs to deal with, but we don't have many customs about exponential growth either, because there have been so few instances of it in human history.

In principle herding should have been one: the more animals you had, the more offspring they'd have. But in practice grazing land was the limiting factor, and there was no plan for growing that exponentially.Or more precisely, no generally applicable plan.

There was a way to grow one's territory exponentially: by conquest. The more territory you control, the more powerful your army becomes, and the easier it is to conquer new territory. This is why history is full of empires.

But so few people created or ran empires that their experiences didn't affect customs very much. The emperor was a remote and terrifying figure, not a source of lessons one could use in one's own life.The most common case of exponential growth in preindustrial times was probably scholarship.

The more you know, the easier it is to learn new things. The result, then as now, was that some people were startlingly more knowledgeable than the rest about certain topics. But this didn't affect customs much either.

Although empires of ideas can overlap and there can thus be far more emperors, in preindustrial times this type of empire had little practical effect. [2]That has changed in the last few centuries. Now the emperors of ideas can design bombs that defeat the emperors of territory.

But this phenomenon is still so new that we haven't fully assimilated it. Few even of the participants realize they're benefitting from exponential growth or ask what they can learn from other instances of it.The other source of superlinear returns is embodied in the expression "winner take all." In a sports match the relationship between performance and return is a step function: the winning team gets one win whether they do much better or just slightly better.

[3]The source of the step function is not competition per se, however. It's that there are thresholds in the outcome. You don't need competition to get those. There can be thresholds in situations where you're the only participant, like proving a theorem or hitting a target.It's remarkable how often a situation with one source of superlinear returns also has the other.

Crossing thresholds leads to exponential growth: the winning side in a battle usually suffers less damage, which makes them more likely to win in the future. And exponential growth helps you cross thresholds: in a market with network effects, a company that grows fast enough can shut out potential competitors.Fame is an interesting example of a phenomenon that combines both sources of superlinear returns.

Fame grows exponentially because existing fans bring you new ones. But the fundamental reason it's so concentrated is thresholds: there's only so much room on the A-list in the average person's head.The most important case combining both sources of superlinear returns may be learning.

Knowledge grows exponentially, but there are also thresholds in it. Learning to ride a bicycle, for example. Some of these thresholds are akin to machine tools: once you learn to read, you're able to learn anything else much faster.

But the most important thresholds of all are those representing new discoveries. Knowledge seems to be fractal in the sense that if you push hard at the boundary of one area of knowledge, you sometimes discover a whole new field.

And if you do, you get first crack at all the new discoveries to be made in it. Newton did this, and so did Durer and Darwin. Are there general rules for finding situations with superlinear returns? The most obvious one is to seek work that compounds.There are two ways work can compound.
It can compound directly, in the sense that doing well in one cycle causes you to do better in the next. That happens for example when you're building infrastructure, or growing an audience or brand.

Or work can compound by teaching you, since learning compounds. This second case is an interesting one because you may feel you're doing badly as it's happening. You may be failing to achieve your immediate goal.

But if you're learning a lot, then you're getting exponential growth nonetheless.This is one reason Silicon Valley is so tolerant of failure. People in Silicon Valley aren't blindly tolerant of failure.

They'll only continue to bet on you if you're learning from your failures. But if you are, you are in fact a good bet: maybe your company didn't grow the way you wanted, but you yourself have, and that should yield results eventually.Indeed, the forms of exponential growth that don't consist of learning are so often intermixed with it that we should probably treat this as the rule rather than the exception.

Which yields another heuristic: always be learning. If you're not learning, you're probably not on a path that leads to superlinear returns.But don't overoptimize what you're learning. Don't limit yourself to learning things that are already known to be valuable.

You're learning; you don't know for sure yet what's going to be valuable, and if you're too strict you'll lop off the outliers.What about step functions? Are there also useful heuristics of the form "seek thresholds" or "seek competition?" Here the situation is trickier.

The existence of a threshold doesn't guarantee the game will be worth playing. If you play a round of Russian roulette, you'll be in a situation with a threshold, certainly, but in the best case you're no better off.

"Seek competition" is similarly useless; what if the prize isn't worth competing for? Sufficiently fast exponential growth guarantees both the shape and magnitude of the return curve — because something that grows fast enough will grow big even if it's trivially small at first — but thresholds only guarantee the shape.

[4]A principle for taking advantage of thresholds has to include a test to ensure the game is worth playing. Here's one that does: if you come across something that's mediocre yet still popular, it could be a good idea to replace it.

For example, if a company makes a product that people dislike yet still buy, then presumably they'd buy a better alternative if you made one. [5]It would be great if there were a way to find promising intellectual thresholds.

Is there a way to tell which questions have whole new fields beyond them? I doubt we could ever predict this with certainty, but the prize is so valuable that it would be useful to have predictors that were even a little better than random, and there's hope of finding those.

We can to some degree predict when a research problem isn't likely to lead to new discoveries: when it seems legit but boring. Whereas the kind that do lead to new discoveries tend to seem very mystifying, but perhaps unimportant.

(If they were mystifying and obviously important, they'd be famous open questions with lots of people already working on them.) So one heuristic here is to be driven by curiosity rather than careerism — to give free rein to your curiosity instead of working on what you're supposed to.

The prospect of superlinear returns for performance is an exciting one for the ambitious. And there's good news in this department: this territory is expanding in both directions. There are more types of work in which you can get superlinear returns, and the returns themselves are growing.There are two reasons for this, though they're so closely intertwined that they're more like one and a half: progress in technology, and the decreasing importance of organizations.Fifty years ago it used to be much more necessary to be part of an organization to work on ambitious projects.

It was the only way to get the resources you needed, the only way to have colleagues, and the only way to get distribution. So in 1970 your prestige was in most cases the prestige of the organization you belonged to.

And prestige was an accurate predictor, because if you weren't part of an organization, you weren't likely to achieve much. There were a handful of exceptions, most notably artists and writers, who worked alone using inexpensive tools and had their own brands.

But even they were at the mercy of organizations for reaching audiences. [6]A world dominated by organizations damped variation in the returns for performance. But this world has eroded significantly just in my lifetime.

Now a lot more people can have the freedom that artists and writers had in the 20th century. There are lots of ambitious projects that don't require much initial funding, and lots of new ways to learn, make money, find colleagues, and reach audiences.There's still plenty of the old world left, but the rate of change has been dramatic by historical standards.

Especially considering what's at stake. It's hard to imagine a more fundamental change than one in the returns for performance.Without the damping effect of institutions, there will be more variation in outcomes.

Which doesn't imply everyone will be better off: people who do well will do even better, but those who do badly will do worse. That's an important point to bear in mind. Exposing oneself to superlinear returns is not for everyone.

Most people will be better off as part of the pool. So who should shoot for superlinear returns? Ambitious people of two types: those who know they're so good that they'll be net ahead in a world with higher variation, and those, particularly the young, who can afford to risk trying it to find out.

[7]The switch away from institutions won't simply be an exodus of their current inhabitants. Many of the new winners will be people they'd never have let in. So the resulting democratization of opportunity will be both greater and more authentic than any tame intramural version the institutions themselves might have cooked up.

Not everyone is happy about this great unlocking of ambition. It threatens some vested interests and contradicts some ideologies. [8] But if you're an ambitious individual it's good news for you. How should you take advantage of it?The most obvious way to take advantage of superlinear returns for performance is by doing exceptionally good work.

At the far end of the curve, incremental effort is a bargain. All the more so because there's less competition at the far end — and not just for the obvious reason that it's hard to do something exceptionally well, but also because people find the prospect so intimidating that few even try.

Which means it's not just a bargain to do exceptional work, but a bargain even to try to.There are many variables that affect how good your work is, and if you want to be an outlier you need to get nearly all of them right.

For example, to do something exceptionally well, you have to be interested in it. Mere diligence is not enough. So in a world with superlinear returns, it's even more valuable to know what you're interested in, and to find ways to work on it.

[9] It will also be important to choose work that suits your circumstances. For example, if there's a kind of work that inherently requires a huge expenditure of time and energy, it will be increasingly valuable to do it when you're young and don't yet have children.There's a surprising amount of technique to doing great work.

It's not just a matter of trying hard. I'm going to take a shot giving a recipe in one paragraph.Choose work you have a natural aptitude for and a deep interest in. Develop a habit of working on your own projects; it doesn't matter what they are so long as you find them excitingly ambitious.

Work as hard as you can without burning out, and this will eventually bring you to one of the frontiers of knowledge. These look smooth from a distance, but up close they're full of gaps. Notice and explore such gaps, and if you're lucky one will expand into a whole new field.

Take as much risk as you can afford; if you're not failing occasionally you're probably being too conservative. Seek out the best colleagues. Develop good taste and learn from the best examples. Be honest, especially with yourself.

Exercise and eat and sleep well and avoid the more dangerous drugs. When in doubt, follow your curiosity. It never lies, and it knows more than you do about what's worth paying attention to. [10]And there is of course one other thing you need: to be lucky.

Luck is always a factor, but it's even more of a factor when you're working on your own rather than as part of an organization. And though there are some valid aphorisms about luck being where preparedness meets opportunity and so on, there's also a component of true chance that you can't do anything about.

The solution is to take multiple shots. Which is another reason to start taking risks early. The best example of a field with superlinear returns is probably science. It has exponential growth, in the form of learning, combined with thresholds at the extreme edge of performance — literally at the limits of knowledge.The result has been a level of inequality in scientific discovery that makes the wealth inequality of even the most stratified societies seem mild by comparison.

Newton's discoveries were arguably greater than all his contemporaries' combined. [11]This point may seem obvious, but it might be just as well to spell it out. Superlinear returns imply inequality. The steeper the return curve, the greater the variation in outcomes.In fact, the correlation between superlinear returns and inequality is so strong that it yields another heuristic for finding work of this type: look for fields where a few big winners outperform everyone else.

A kind of work where everyone does about the same is unlikely to be one with superlinear returns.What are fields where a few big winners outperform everyone else? Here are some obvious ones: sports, politics, art, music, acting, directing, writing, math, science, starting companies, and investing.

In sports the phenomenon is due to externally imposed thresholds; you only need to be a few percent faster to win every race. In politics, power grows much as it did in the days of emperors. And in some of the other fields (including politics) success is driven largely by fame, which has its own source of superlinear growth.

But when we exclude sports and politics and the effects of fame, a remarkable pattern emerges: the remaining list is exactly the same as the list of fields where you have to be independent-minded to succeed — where your ideas have to be not just correct, but novel as well.

[12]This is obviously the case in science. You can't publish papers saying things that other people have already said. But it's just as true in investing, for example. It's only useful to believe that a company will do well if most other investors don't; if everyone else thinks the company will do well, then its stock price will already reflect that, and there's no room to make money.What else can we learn from these fields?

In all of them you have to put in the initial effort. Superlinear returns seem small at first. At this rate, you find yourself thinking, I'll never get anywhere. But because the reward curve rises so steeply at the far end, it's worth taking extraordinary measures to get there.In the startup world, the name for this principle is "do things that don't scale." If you pay a ridiculous amount of attention to your tiny initial set of customers, ideally you'll kick off exponential growth by word of mouth.

But this same principle applies to anything that grows exponentially. Learning, for example. When you first start learning something, you feel lost. But it's worth making the initial effort to get a toehold, because the more you learn, the easier it will get.There's another more subtle lesson in the list of fields with superlinear returns: not to equate work with a job.

For most of the 20th century the two were identical for nearly everyone, and as a result we've inherited a custom that equates productivity with having a job. Even now to most people the phrase "your work" means their job.

But to a writer or artist or scientist it means whatever they're currently studying or creating. For someone like that, their work is something they carry with them from job to job, if they have jobs at all.

It may be done for an employer, but it's part of their portfolio. It's an intimidating prospect to enter a field where a few big winners outperform everyone else. Some people do this deliberately, but you don't need to.

If you have sufficient natural ability and you follow your curiosity sufficiently far, you'll end up in one. Your curiosity won't let you be interested in boring questions, and interesting questions tend to create fields with superlinear returns if they're not already part of one.The territory of superlinear returns is by no means static.

Indeed, the most extreme returns come from expanding it. So while both ambition and curiosity can get you into this territory, curiosity may be the more powerful of the two. Ambition tends to make you climb existing peaks, but if you stick close enough to an interesting enough question, it may grow into a mountain beneath you.NotesThere's a limit to how sharply you can distinguish between effort, performance, and return, because they're not sharply distinguished in fact.

What counts as return to one person might be performance to another. But though the borders of these concepts are blurry, they're not meaningless. I've tried to write about them as precisely as I could without crossing into error.[1] Evolution itself is probably the most pervasive example of superlinear returns for performance.

But this is hard for us to empathize with because we're not the recipients; we're the returns.[2] Knowledge did of course have a practical effect before the Industrial Revolution. The development of agriculture changed human life completely.

But this kind of change was the result of broad, gradual improvements in technique, not the discoveries of a few exceptionally learned people.[3] It's not mathematically correct to describe a step function as superlinear, but a step function starting from zero works like a superlinear function when it describes the reward curve for effort by a rational actor.

If it starts at zero then the part before the step is below any linearly increasing return, and the part after the step must be above the necessary return at that point or no one would bother.[4] Seeking competition could be a good heuristic in the sense that some people find it motivating.

It's also somewhat of a guide to promising problems, because it's a sign that other people find them promising. But it's a very imperfect sign: often there's a clamoring crowd chasing some problem, and they all end up being trumped by someone quietly working on another one.[5] Not always, though.

You have to be careful with this rule. When something is popular despite being mediocre, there's often a hidden reason why. Perhaps monopoly or regulation make it hard to compete. Perhaps customers have bad taste or have broken procedures for deciding what to buy.

There are huge swathes of mediocre things that exist for such reasons.[6] In my twenties I wanted to be an artist and even went to art school to study painting. Mostly because I liked art, but a nontrivial part of my motivation came from the fact that artists seemed least at the mercy of organizations.[7] In principle everyone is getting superlinear returns.

Learning compounds, and everyone learns in the course of their life. But in practice few push this kind of everyday learning to the point where the return curve gets really steep.[8] It's unclear exactly what advocates of "equity" mean by it.

They seem to disagree among themselves. But whatever they mean is probably at odds with a world in which institutions have less power to control outcomes, and a handful of outliers do much better than everyone else.It may seem like bad luck for this concept that it arose at just the moment when the world was shifting in the opposite direction, but I don't think this was a coincidence.

I think one reason it arose now is because its adherents feel threatened by rapidly increasing variation in performance.[9] Corollary: Parents who pressure their kids to work on something prestigious, like medicine, even though they have no interest in it, will be hosing them even more than they have in the past.[10] The original version of this paragraph was the first draft of "How to Do Great Work." As soon as I wrote it I realized it was a more important topic than superlinear returns, so I paused the present essay to expand this paragraph into its own.

Practically nothing remains of the original version, because after I finished "How to Do Great Work" I rewrote it based on that.[11] Before the Industrial Revolution, people who got rich usually did it like emperors: capturing some resource made them more powerful and enabled them to capture more.

Now it can be done like a scientist, by discovering or building something uniquely valuable. Most people who get rich use a mix of the old and the new ways, but in the most advanced economies the ratio has shifted dramatically toward discovery just in the last half century.[12] It's not surprising that conventional-minded people would dislike inequality if independent-mindedness is one of the biggest drivers of it.

But it's not simply that they don't want anyone to have what they can't. The conventional-minded literally can't imagine what it's like to have novel ideas. So the whole phenomenon of great variation in performance seems unnatural to them, and when they encounter it they assume it must be due to cheating or to some malign external influence.Thanks to Trevor Blackwell, Patrick Collison, Tyler Cowen, Jessica Livingston, Harj Taggar, and Garry Tan for reading drafts of this.

paragraphs.original: Although empires of ideas can overlap and there can thus be far more emperors, in preindustrial times this type of empire had little practical effect. [2]That has changed in the last few centuries. Now the emperors of ideas can design bombs that defeat the emperors of territory.
paragraphs.translated: 尽管思想的帝国可以相互重叠，因此可以有更多这样的“皇帝”，但在前工业时代，这种帝国几乎没有什么实际影响。在过去几个世纪中，这种情况发生了变化。如今，思想的“皇帝”可以设计出击败领土“皇帝”的炸弹。

paragraphs.original: But this phenomenon is still so new that we haven't fully assimilated it. Few even of the participants realize they're benefitting from exponential growth or ask what they can learn from other instances of it.The other source of superlinear returns is embodied in the expression "winner take all." In a sports match the relationship between performance and return is a step function: the winning team gets one win whether they do much better or just slightly better.
paragraphs.translated: 但这一现象仍如此新颖，以至于我们尚未完全消化吸收。即使是参与者，也很少有人意识到自己正受益于指数增长，或思考可以从其他类似情况中学到什么。超线性回报的另一个来源体现在“赢家通吃”这一表述中。在体育比赛中，表现与回报之间的关系是一个阶跃函数：获胜的队伍无论表现得多好或只是略胜一筹，都只能获得一场胜利。

paragraphs.original: [3]The source of the step function is not competition per se, however. It's that there are thresholds in the outcome. You don't need competition to get those. There can be thresholds in situations where you're the only participant, like proving a theorem or hitting a target.It's remarkable how often a situation with one source of superlinear returns also has the other.
paragraphs.translated: [3]然而，阶跃函数的来源并不是竞争本身。而是结果中存在阈值。即使没有竞争，这些阈值也会存在。在只有你一个人参与的情况下，比如证明一个定理或击中一个目标，也可能存在阈值。值得注意的是，一个具有超线性回报来源的情况往往也会有另一个来源。

paragraphs.original: Crossing thresholds leads to exponential growth: the winning side in a battle usually suffers less damage, which makes them more likely to win in the future. And exponential growth helps you cross thresholds: in a market with network effects, a company that grows fast enough can shut out potential competitors.Fame is an interesting example of a phenomenon that combines both sources of superlinear returns.
paragraphs.translated: 越过阈值会导致指数增长：在战斗中获胜的一方通常遭受的损失较小，这使得他们在未来更有可能获胜。而指数增长有助于越过阈值：在网络效应显著的市场中，增长足够快的公司可以将潜在竞争对手拒之门外。名声是一个有趣的现象，它结合了这两种超线性回报的来源。

paragraphs.original: Fame grows exponentially because existing fans bring you new ones. But the fundamental reason it's so concentrated is thresholds: there's only so much room on the A-list in the average person's head.The most important case combining both sources of superlinear returns may be learning.
paragraphs.translated: 名声呈指数级增长，因为现有的粉丝会为你带来新粉丝。但其高度集中的根本原因在于门槛：普通人头脑中的A级名单位置是有限的。将这两种超线性回报来源结合得最重要的例子可能是学习。

paragraphs.original: Knowledge grows exponentially, but there are also thresholds in it. Learning to ride a bicycle, for example. Some of these thresholds are akin to machine tools: once you learn to read, you're able to learn anything else much faster.
paragraphs.translated: 知识呈指数增长，但其中也存在门槛。比如学习骑自行车。有些门槛类似于机床：一旦学会了阅读，你就能更快地学习其他任何东西。

paragraphs.original: But the most important thresholds of all are those representing new discoveries. Knowledge seems to be fractal in the sense that if you push hard at the boundary of one area of knowledge, you sometimes discover a whole new field.
paragraphs.translated: 但最重要的门槛是那些代表新发现的。知识似乎具有分形的特性，也就是说，如果你在某个知识领域的边界上深入探索，有时会发现一个全新的领域。

paragraphs.original: And if you do, you get first crack at all the new discoveries to be made in it. Newton did this, and so did Durer and Darwin. Are there general rules for finding situations with superlinear returns? The most obvious one is to seek work that compounds.There are two ways work can compound.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你这样做，你将有机会率先发现其中的所有新事物。牛顿、丢勒和达尔文都是这样做的。是否有一般规则可以找到具有超线性回报的情况？最明显的一个规则是寻找可以累积的工作。工作可以通过两种方式累积。

paragraphs.original: It can compound directly, in the sense that doing well in one cycle causes you to do better in the next. That happens for example when you're building infrastructure, or growing an audience or brand.
paragraphs.translated: 它可以直接累积，也就是说在一个周期中表现良好会使得你在下一个周期中表现得更好。例如，当你在建设基础设施、扩大受众或品牌时，就会发生这种情况。

paragraphs.original: Or work can compound by teaching you, since learning compounds. This second case is an interesting one because you may feel you're doing badly as it's happening. You may be failing to achieve your immediate goal.
paragraphs.translated: 或者，工作可以通过教你知识而产生累积效应，因为学习本身就是一种累积过程。第二种情况很有趣，因为在这个过程中你可能会觉得自己的表现很差。你可能无法实现眼前的目标。

paragraphs.original: But if you're learning a lot, then you're getting exponential growth nonetheless.This is one reason Silicon Valley is so tolerant of failure. People in Silicon Valley aren't blindly tolerant of failure.
paragraphs.translated: 但如果你学到了很多，那你仍然在实现指数级增长。这就是为什么硅谷对失败如此宽容的原因之一。硅谷的人并不是盲目地对失败宽容。

paragraphs.original: They'll only continue to bet on you if you're learning from your failures. But if you are, you are in fact a good bet: maybe your company didn't grow the way you wanted, but you yourself have, and that should yield results eventually.Indeed, the forms of exponential growth that don't consist of learning are so often intermixed with it that we should probably treat this as the rule rather than the exception.
paragraphs.translated: 只有当你从失败中学习时，他们才会继续支持你。但如果你确实在这样做，那你实际上是一个值得投资的对象：也许你的公司没有按照你希望的方式发展，但你自身已经成长了，这最终应该会带来成果。事实上，那些不包含学习的指数增长形式往往与学习交织在一起，以至于我们或许应该将其视为常态而非例外。

paragraphs.original: Which yields another heuristic: always be learning. If you're not learning, you're probably not on a path that leads to superlinear returns.But don't overoptimize what you're learning. Don't limit yourself to learning things that are already known to be valuable.
paragraphs.translated: 这引出了另一个启发式原则：始终学习。如果你不学习，你可能就不是在一条能带来超线性回报的道路上。但不要过度优化你的学习内容。不要局限于学习那些已知有价值的东西。

paragraphs.original: You're learning; you don't know for sure yet what's going to be valuable, and if you're too strict you'll lop off the outliers.What about step functions? Are there also useful heuristics of the form "seek thresholds" or "seek competition?" Here the situation is trickier.
paragraphs.translated: 你正在学习；你还不能确定什么会是有价值的，如果你过于严格，就会砍掉那些异常值。那么，阶跃函数呢？是否存在“寻找阈值”或“寻找竞争”的有用启发式方法？在这里，情况更加复杂。

paragraphs.original: The existence of a threshold doesn't guarantee the game will be worth playing. If you play a round of Russian roulette, you'll be in a situation with a threshold, certainly, but in the best case you're no better off.
paragraphs.translated: 存在一个门槛并不能保证游戏值得一玩。如果你玩一轮俄罗斯轮盘赌，你确实会面临一个门槛，但即使在最好的情况下，你也毫无收获。

paragraphs.original: "Seek competition" is similarly useless; what if the prize isn't worth competing for? Sufficiently fast exponential growth guarantees both the shape and magnitude of the return curve — because something that grows fast enough will grow big even if it's trivially small at first — but thresholds only guarantee the shape.
paragraphs.translated: “寻求竞争”同样无用；如果奖品不值得竞争怎么办？足够快的指数增长保证了回报曲线的形状和规模——因为发展足够快的事物即使最初微不足道，最终也会变得庞大——但阈值只能保证形状。

paragraphs.original: [4]A principle for taking advantage of thresholds has to include a test to ensure the game is worth playing. Here's one that does: if you come across something that's mediocre yet still popular, it could be a good idea to replace it.
paragraphs.translated: 利用阈值的一个原则必须包括一个测试，以确保游戏值得一玩。这里有一个符合条件的方法：如果你遇到某事物虽然平庸但仍然很受欢迎，那么替换它可能是一个好主意。

paragraphs.original: For example, if a company makes a product that people dislike yet still buy, then presumably they'd buy a better alternative if you made one. [5]It would be great if there were a way to find promising intellectual thresholds.
paragraphs.translated: 例如，如果一家公司的产品虽然人们不喜欢但仍然购买，那么可以假设，如果你制作了一个更好的替代品，他们就会购买。[5]如果有一种方法可以找到有前景的知识门槛，那将是非常好的。

paragraphs.original: Is there a way to tell which questions have whole new fields beyond them? I doubt we could ever predict this with certainty, but the prize is so valuable that it would be useful to have predictors that were even a little better than random, and there's hope of finding those.
paragraphs.translated: 有没有办法判断哪些问题背后隐藏着全新的领域？我怀疑我们永远无法确切地预测这一点，但这种预测的价值如此之大，以至于即使有一些比随机猜测稍好一点的预测指标也会很有用，而且我们有希望找到这些指标。

paragraphs.original: We can to some degree predict when a research problem isn't likely to lead to new discoveries: when it seems legit but boring. Whereas the kind that do lead to new discoveries tend to seem very mystifying, but perhaps unimportant.
paragraphs.translated: 我们可以在某种程度上预测一个研究问题是否不太可能带来新发现：当它看起来合理但乏味时。而那些确实能带来新发现的问题往往显得非常令人困惑，但可能不那么重要。

paragraphs.original: (If they were mystifying and obviously important, they'd be famous open questions with lots of people already working on them.) So one heuristic here is to be driven by curiosity rather than careerism — to give free rein to your curiosity instead of working on what you're supposed to.
paragraphs.translated: （如果它们既令人费解又明显重要，那么它们就会成为许多人都在研究的著名开放问题。）因此，这里的一个经验法则是由好奇心而不是功利心驱动——让你的好奇心自由发挥，而不是去做你认为应该做的事情。

paragraphs.original: The prospect of superlinear returns for performance is an exciting one for the ambitious. And there's good news in this department: this territory is expanding in both directions. There are more types of work in which you can get superlinear returns, and the returns themselves are growing.There are two reasons for this, though they're so closely intertwined that they're more like one and a half: progress in technology, and the decreasing importance of organizations.Fifty years ago it used to be much more necessary to be part of an organization to work on ambitious projects.
paragraphs.translated: 对于雄心勃勃的人来说，性能的超线性回报前景令人振奋。而且在这方面有好消息：这一领域正在向两个方向扩展。你可以获得超线性回报的工作类型越来越多，而且回报本身也在增长。造成这一现象的原因有两个，尽管它们联系如此紧密，可以说是一个半原因：技术的进步和组织的重要性降低。五十年前，要想从事雄心勃勃的项目，成为某个组织的一员几乎是必不可少的。

paragraphs.original: It was the only way to get the resources you needed, the only way to have colleagues, and the only way to get distribution. So in 1970 your prestige was in most cases the prestige of the organization you belonged to.
paragraphs.translated: 这是获得所需资源的唯一途径，是拥有同事的唯一方式，也是获得分发渠道的唯一方法。因此，在1970年，你的声望在大多数情况下是你所属组织的声望。

paragraphs.original: And prestige was an accurate predictor, because if you weren't part of an organization, you weren't likely to achieve much. There were a handful of exceptions, most notably artists and writers, who worked alone using inexpensive tools and had their own brands.
paragraphs.translated: 声望是一个准确的预测指标，因为如果你不属于某个组织，就不太可能取得太大的成就。当然也有一些例外，最显著的是艺术家和作家，他们使用成本低廉的工具独立工作，并拥有自己的品牌。

paragraphs.original: But even they were at the mercy of organizations for reaching audiences. [6]A world dominated by organizations damped variation in the returns for performance. But this world has eroded significantly just in my lifetime.
paragraphs.translated: 但即使是他们，也受制于组织以接触观众。[6]一个由组织主导的世界抑制了绩效回报的差异。但在我有生之年，这个世界已经显著瓦解。

paragraphs.original: Now a lot more people can have the freedom that artists and writers had in the 20th century. There are lots of ambitious projects that don't require much initial funding, and lots of new ways to learn, make money, find colleagues, and reach audiences.There's still plenty of the old world left, but the rate of change has been dramatic by historical standards.
paragraphs.translated: 现在，更多的人可以享受到20世纪艺术家和作家所拥有的自由。有许多雄心勃勃的项目并不需要太多初始资金，也有许多新的方法来学习、赚钱、寻找合作伙伴和接触观众。旧世界依然存在，但按历史标准来看，变化的速度已经非常显著。

paragraphs.original: Especially considering what's at stake. It's hard to imagine a more fundamental change than one in the returns for performance.Without the damping effect of institutions, there will be more variation in outcomes.
paragraphs.translated: 特别是考虑到利害关系。很难想象比绩效回报的变化更根本的改变。如果没有机构的抑制作用，结果的差异将会更大。

paragraphs.original: Which doesn't imply everyone will be better off: people who do well will do even better, but those who do badly will do worse. That's an important point to bear in mind. Exposing oneself to superlinear returns is not for everyone.
paragraphs.translated: 这并不意味着每个人都会过得更好：那些表现优秀的人会更加出色，但那些表现不佳的人会更差。这是一个需要牢记的重要观点。接触超线性回报并不适合所有人。

paragraphs.original: Most people will be better off as part of the pool. So who should shoot for superlinear returns? Ambitious people of two types: those who know they're so good that they'll be net ahead in a world with higher variation, and those, particularly the young, who can afford to risk trying it to find out.
paragraphs.translated: 大多数人作为群体的一部分会过得更好。那么，谁应该追求超线性回报呢？两类有雄心的人：一类是那些知道自己非常优秀，以至于在差异更大的世界中依然能领先的人；另一类是那些特别年轻，可以承担风险去尝试并发现自我的人。

paragraphs.original: [7]The switch away from institutions won't simply be an exodus of their current inhabitants. Many of the new winners will be people they'd never have let in. So the resulting democratization of opportunity will be both greater and more authentic than any tame intramural version the institutions themselves might have cooked up.
paragraphs.translated: [7]从机构中退出的转变不仅仅意味着其现有成员的出走。许多新的胜利者将是那些他们从未允许进入的人。因此，由此产生的机会民主化将比这些机构自身可能策划的任何温和的内部版本都要更加广泛和真实。

paragraphs.original: Not everyone is happy about this great unlocking of ambition. It threatens some vested interests and contradicts some ideologies. [8] But if you're an ambitious individual it's good news for you. How should you take advantage of it?The most obvious way to take advantage of superlinear returns for performance is by doing exceptionally good work.
paragraphs.translated: 并非每个人都对这种雄心壮志的极大释放感到高兴。它威胁到某些既得利益，并与某些意识形态相矛盾。[8] 但如果你是一个有雄心的人，这对你来说是个好消息。你应该如何利用这一机会？最明显的方法是通过做出异常出色的工作来利用绩效的超线性回报。

paragraphs.original: At the far end of the curve, incremental effort is a bargain. All the more so because there's less competition at the far end — and not just for the obvious reason that it's hard to do something exceptionally well, but also because people find the prospect so intimidating that few even try.
paragraphs.translated: 在曲线的远端，额外的努力是一笔划算的交易。这一点尤为重要，因为远端的竞争较少——这不仅是因为做到出类拔萃很难，还因为人们觉得这种前景如此令人望而生畏，以至于很少有人愿意尝试。

paragraphs.original: Which means it's not just a bargain to do exceptional work, but a bargain even to try to.There are many variables that affect how good your work is, and if you want to be an outlier you need to get nearly all of them right.
paragraphs.translated: 这意味着，不仅要出色地完成工作是划算的，甚至尝试这样做也是划算的。影响你工作质量的因素有很多，如果你想成为出类拔萃的人，就需要几乎把所有这些因素都处理好。

paragraphs.original: For example, to do something exceptionally well, you have to be interested in it. Mere diligence is not enough. So in a world with superlinear returns, it's even more valuable to know what you're interested in, and to find ways to work on it.
paragraphs.translated: 例如，要将某件事做得出类拔萃，你必须对它感兴趣。光有勤奋是不够的。因此，在一个收益递增的世界里，了解自己的兴趣所在，并找到方法来从事这些工作，就显得更加重要。

paragraphs.original: [9] It will also be important to choose work that suits your circumstances. For example, if there's a kind of work that inherently requires a huge expenditure of time and energy, it will be increasingly valuable to do it when you're young and don't yet have children.There's a surprising amount of technique to doing great work.
paragraphs.translated: [9] 选择适合你处境的工作也非常重要。例如，如果某类工作本质上就需要大量时间和精力的投入，那么当你年轻且尚未有子女时去做这类工作将越来越有价值。做好出色工作其实需要掌握相当多的技巧。

paragraphs.original: It's not just a matter of trying hard. I'm going to take a shot giving a recipe in one paragraph.Choose work you have a natural aptitude for and a deep interest in. Develop a habit of working on your own projects; it doesn't matter what they are so long as you find them excitingly ambitious.
paragraphs.translated: 这不仅仅是一个努力的问题。我将尝试用一段话给出一个建议。选择你天生擅长且深感兴趣的领域。养成自己动手做项目的好习惯；无论这些项目是什么，只要你觉得它们雄心勃勃，令人兴奋即可。

paragraphs.original: Work as hard as you can without burning out, and this will eventually bring you to one of the frontiers of knowledge. These look smooth from a distance, but up close they're full of gaps. Notice and explore such gaps, and if you're lucky one will expand into a whole new field.
paragraphs.translated: 尽你所能努力工作，但不要透支自己，这最终会将你带到知识的前沿之一。从远处看，这些前沿似乎很平滑，但近看却充满了空白。注意并探索这些空白，如果你足够幸运，其中一个可能会扩展成一个全新的领域。

paragraphs.original: Take as much risk as you can afford; if you're not failing occasionally you're probably being too conservative. Seek out the best colleagues. Develop good taste and learn from the best examples. Be honest, especially with yourself.
paragraphs.translated: 承担你能承受的最大风险；如果你偶尔不失败，那你可能过于保守了。寻找最优秀的同事。培养良好的品味，向最佳范例学习。诚实，尤其是对自己。

paragraphs.original: Exercise and eat and sleep well and avoid the more dangerous drugs. When in doubt, follow your curiosity. It never lies, and it knows more than you do about what's worth paying attention to. [10]And there is of course one other thing you need: to be lucky.
paragraphs.translated: 多做运动，好好吃饭，保证充足睡眠，远离危险的药物。当感到不确定时，跟随你的好奇心。它从不撒谎，而且它比你更清楚什么值得去关注。当然，你还需要一样东西：运气。

paragraphs.original: Luck is always a factor, but it's even more of a factor when you're working on your own rather than as part of an organization. And though there are some valid aphorisms about luck being where preparedness meets opportunity and so on, there's also a component of true chance that you can't do anything about.
paragraphs.translated: 运气总是一个因素，但当你独自工作而不是作为组织的一部分时，运气的影响更为显著。尽管有一些关于运气是准备与机会相遇的说法是合理的，但也存在一个你无法控制的真正偶然性成分。

paragraphs.original: The solution is to take multiple shots. Which is another reason to start taking risks early. The best example of a field with superlinear returns is probably science. It has exponential growth, in the form of learning, combined with thresholds at the extreme edge of performance — literally at the limits of knowledge.The result has been a level of inequality in scientific discovery that makes the wealth inequality of even the most stratified societies seem mild by comparison.
paragraphs.translated: 解决方案是多做几次尝试。这也是尽早承担风险的另一个原因。超级线性回报的领域中，科学可能是最好的例子。它以学习的形式实现了指数增长，同时在性能的极限边缘——实际上是在知识的极限处——设定了门槛。其结果是科学发现中的不平等程度，即使是最分层的社会的财富不平等相比之下也显得温和。

paragraphs.original: Newton's discoveries were arguably greater than all his contemporaries' combined. [11]This point may seem obvious, but it might be just as well to spell it out. Superlinear returns imply inequality. The steeper the return curve, the greater the variation in outcomes.In fact, the correlation between superlinear returns and inequality is so strong that it yields another heuristic for finding work of this type: look for fields where a few big winners outperform everyone else.
paragraphs.translated: 牛顿的发现可以说比他所有同时代人的加起来还要伟大。[11]这一点可能看起来显而易见，但还是值得明确指出。超线性回报意味着不平等。回报曲线越陡峭，结果的差异就越大。实际上，超线性回报与不平等之间的关联如此强烈，以至于它提供了一个寻找此类工作的另一种经验法则：寻找那些少数大赢家超越其他所有人的领域。

paragraphs.original: A kind of work where everyone does about the same is unlikely to be one with superlinear returns.What are fields where a few big winners outperform everyone else? Here are some obvious ones: sports, politics, art, music, acting, directing, writing, math, science, starting companies, and investing.
paragraphs.translated: 一种每个人都做得差不多的工作不太可能是具有超线性回报的工作。哪些领域会有少数大赢家超越其他人？这里有一些显而易见的例子：体育、政治、艺术、音乐、表演、导演、写作、数学、科学、创办公司和投资。

paragraphs.original: In sports the phenomenon is due to externally imposed thresholds; you only need to be a few percent faster to win every race. In politics, power grows much as it did in the days of emperors. And in some of the other fields (including politics) success is driven largely by fame, which has its own source of superlinear growth.
paragraphs.translated: 在体育中，这种现象是由于外部强加的门槛造成的；你只需要快上几个百分点就能赢得每场比赛。在政治中，权力的增长方式与皇帝时代相似。而在其他一些领域（包括政治），成功在很大程度上是由名声驱动的，而名声本身也有其超线性增长的来源。

paragraphs.original: But when we exclude sports and politics and the effects of fame, a remarkable pattern emerges: the remaining list is exactly the same as the list of fields where you have to be independent-minded to succeed — where your ideas have to be not just correct, but novel as well.
paragraphs.translated: 但当我们排除体育、政治以及名声的影响后，一个显著的模式显现出来：剩下的列表与那些你需要有独立思考能力才能成功的领域完全相同——在这些领域，你的想法不仅必须正确，还必须具有创新性。

paragraphs.original: [12]This is obviously the case in science. You can't publish papers saying things that other people have already said. But it's just as true in investing, for example. It's only useful to believe that a company will do well if most other investors don't; if everyone else thinks the company will do well, then its stock price will already reflect that, and there's no room to make money.What else can we learn from these fields?
paragraphs.translated: [12]这在科学领域显然是如此。你不能发表论文说别人已经说过的事情。但在投资领域也是如此。只有当大多数其他投资者不认为一家公司会表现良好时，相信这家公司会成功才是有用的；如果所有人都认为这家公司会表现良好，那么其股价已经反映了这一点，就没有盈利的空间了。我们还能从这些领域学到什么？

paragraphs.original: In all of them you have to put in the initial effort. Superlinear returns seem small at first. At this rate, you find yourself thinking, I'll never get anywhere. But because the reward curve rises so steeply at the far end, it's worth taking extraordinary measures to get there.In the startup world, the name for this principle is "do things that don't scale." If you pay a ridiculous amount of attention to your tiny initial set of customers, ideally you'll kick off exponential growth by word of mouth.
paragraphs.translated: 在所有这些情况下，你都必须付出最初的 effort。超线性回报一开始看起来很小。以这个速度，你会觉得自己永远也达不到目标。但因为回报曲线在远端上升得非常陡峭，所以值得采取非同寻常的措施来达到那里。在创业世界中，这一原则被称为“做不具扩展性的事情”。如果你对最初那少量顾客给予极度的关注，理想情况下，你会通过口碑引发指数级增长。

paragraphs.original: But this same principle applies to anything that grows exponentially. Learning, for example. When you first start learning something, you feel lost. But it's worth making the initial effort to get a toehold, because the more you learn, the easier it will get.There's another more subtle lesson in the list of fields with superlinear returns: not to equate work with a job.
paragraphs.translated: 但这一原则同样适用于任何呈指数增长的事物。比如学习。当你刚开始学习某样东西时，可能会感到迷茫。但值得在初期付出努力，以获得一个立足点，因为学得越多，就会变得越容易。从具有超线性回报的领域列表中，还可以得到一个更微妙的教训：不要将工作等同于职业。

paragraphs.original: For most of the 20th century the two were identical for nearly everyone, and as a result we've inherited a custom that equates productivity with having a job. Even now to most people the phrase "your work" means their job.
paragraphs.translated: 在20世纪的大部分时间里，对几乎所有人来说，这两个概念是相同的，因此我们继承了一种将生产力等同于有工作的习俗。即使到现在，对大多数人来说，“你的工作”这句话仍然指的是他们的职业。

paragraphs.original: But to a writer or artist or scientist it means whatever they're currently studying or creating. For someone like that, their work is something they carry with them from job to job, if they have jobs at all.
paragraphs.translated: 但对于作家、艺术家或科学家来说，这指的是他们当前正在研究或创作的内容。对于这样的人来说，他们的工作是他们无论是否有工作都会随身携带的东西。

paragraphs.original: It may be done for an employer, but it's part of their portfolio. It's an intimidating prospect to enter a field where a few big winners outperform everyone else. Some people do this deliberately, but you don't need to.
paragraphs.translated: 这可能是为雇主做的，但它是他们作品集的一部分。进入一个少数几个大赢家超越所有人的领域，这确实令人望而生畏。有些人是故意这样做的，但你并不需要如此。

paragraphs.original: If you have sufficient natural ability and you follow your curiosity sufficiently far, you'll end up in one. Your curiosity won't let you be interested in boring questions, and interesting questions tend to create fields with superlinear returns if they're not already part of one.The territory of superlinear returns is by no means static.
paragraphs.translated: 如果你有足够的天赋，并且能够充分追随你的好奇心，最终你会进入一个这样的领域。你的好奇心不会让你对无聊的问题感兴趣，而有趣的问题如果还没有成为某个领域的一部分，往往会创造出具有超线性回报的领域。超线性回报的领域绝非一成不变。

paragraphs.original: Indeed, the most extreme returns come from expanding it. So while both ambition and curiosity can get you into this territory, curiosity may be the more powerful of the two. Ambition tends to make you climb existing peaks, but if you stick close enough to an interesting enough question, it may grow into a mountain beneath you.NotesThere's a limit to how sharply you can distinguish between effort, performance, and return, because they're not sharply distinguished in fact.
paragraphs.translated: 确实，最极端的回报来自于扩大它。因此，虽然雄心和好奇心都能带你进入这个领域，但好奇心可能是两者中更强大的。雄心往往让你攀登现有的高峰，但如果你足够接近一个足够有趣的问题，它可能会在你脚下长成一座山。注：努力、表现和回报之间的区别是有限的，因为事实上它们并不是截然分开的。

paragraphs.original: What counts as return to one person might be performance to another. But though the borders of these concepts are blurry, they're not meaningless. I've tried to write about them as precisely as I could without crossing into error.[1] Evolution itself is probably the most pervasive example of superlinear returns for performance.
paragraphs.translated: 对一个人来说是回报的东西，对另一个人来说可能是表现。虽然这些概念的边界是模糊的，但它们并非毫无意义。我尽量精确地描述它们，同时避免出现错误。[1] 进化本身可能是表现产生超线性回报的最普遍例子。

paragraphs.original: But this is hard for us to empathize with because we're not the recipients; we're the returns.[2] Knowledge did of course have a practical effect before the Industrial Revolution. The development of agriculture changed human life completely.
paragraphs.translated: 但这一点我们很难感同身受，因为我们不是接收者，而是被退回的一方。[2] 当然，在工业革命之前，知识确实具有实际效果。农业的发展彻底改变了人类的生活。

paragraphs.original: But this kind of change was the result of broad, gradual improvements in technique, not the discoveries of a few exceptionally learned people.[3] It's not mathematically correct to describe a step function as superlinear, but a step function starting from zero works like a superlinear function when it describes the reward curve for effort by a rational actor.
paragraphs.translated: 但这种变化是技术广泛且逐渐改进的结果，而不是少数学识渊博的人的发现所致。[3] 从数学上来说，将阶跃函数描述为超线性的并不正确，但当阶跃函数从零开始描述理性行为者的努力回报曲线时，其表现类似于超线性函数。

paragraphs.original: If it starts at zero then the part before the step is below any linearly increasing return, and the part after the step must be above the necessary return at that point or no one would bother.[4] Seeking competition could be a good heuristic in the sense that some people find it motivating.
paragraphs.translated: 如果从零开始，那么步骤前的部分将低于任何线性增长的回报，而步骤后的部分必须高于该点所需的回报，否则没有人会费心去做。[4] 寻求竞争可能是一个很好的启发式方法，因为有些人发现这很有动力。

paragraphs.original: It's also somewhat of a guide to promising problems, because it's a sign that other people find them promising. But it's a very imperfect sign: often there's a clamoring crowd chasing some problem, and they all end up being trumped by someone quietly working on another one.[5] Not always, though.
paragraphs.translated: 这在某种程度上也是一份指引，指向那些有前景的问题，因为这表明其他人也认为这些问题有潜力。但这是一个非常不完美的信号：常常有一群人追逐某个问题，最终却被另一个人安静地解决另一个问题而超越。不过，这种情况并非总是如此。

paragraphs.original: You have to be careful with this rule. When something is popular despite being mediocre, there's often a hidden reason why. Perhaps monopoly or regulation make it hard to compete. Perhaps customers have bad taste or have broken procedures for deciding what to buy.
paragraphs.translated: 你必须对此规则保持谨慎。当某样东西尽管平庸却依然流行时，通常背后隐藏着原因。可能是垄断或监管使得竞争变得困难。可能是客户品味不佳或决策程序有缺陷，导致他们做出了错误的购买决定。

paragraphs.original: There are huge swathes of mediocre things that exist for such reasons.[6] In my twenties I wanted to be an artist and even went to art school to study painting. Mostly because I liked art, but a nontrivial part of my motivation came from the fact that artists seemed least at the mercy of organizations.[7] In principle everyone is getting superlinear returns.
paragraphs.translated: 有大量平庸的事物之所以存在，正是出于这样的原因。[6] 在我二十多岁的时候，我想成为一名艺术家，甚至去艺术学校学习绘画。主要是因为我喜欢艺术，但我的动机中有一部分也来自于艺术家似乎最少受制于组织这一点。[7] 从原则上讲，每个人都在获得超线性的回报。

paragraphs.original: Learning compounds, and everyone learns in the course of their life. But in practice few push this kind of everyday learning to the point where the return curve gets really steep.[8] It's unclear exactly what advocates of "equity" mean by it.
paragraphs.translated: 学习是一种积累，每个人在生命的过程中都会学习。但在实践中，很少有人将这种日常学习推向回报曲线急剧上升的阶段。[8] 尚不清楚“公平”的倡导者具体指的是什么。

paragraphs.original: They seem to disagree among themselves. But whatever they mean is probably at odds with a world in which institutions have less power to control outcomes, and a handful of outliers do much better than everyone else.It may seem like bad luck for this concept that it arose at just the moment when the world was shifting in the opposite direction, but I don't think this was a coincidence.
paragraphs.translated: 他们似乎在彼此之间存在分歧。但他们所说的可能与一个机构对结果的控制力减弱，而少数例外者比其他人表现得好的世界相矛盾。这一概念恰好在世界向相反方向转变的时刻出现，看起来像是不幸，但我认为这并非巧合。

paragraphs.original: I think one reason it arose now is because its adherents feel threatened by rapidly increasing variation in performance.[9] Corollary: Parents who pressure their kids to work on something prestigious, like medicine, even though they have no interest in it, will be hosing them even more than they have in the past.[10] The original version of this paragraph was the first draft of "How to Do Great Work." As soon as I wrote it I realized it was a more important topic than superlinear returns, so I paused the present essay to expand this paragraph into its own.
paragraphs.translated: 我认为它现在出现的一个原因是，其支持者感到受到迅速增加的绩效差异的威胁。[9] 推论：父母迫使孩子从事他们不感兴趣的声望职业，如医学，即使孩子对这些领域毫无兴趣，也会比过去更加耽误孩子。[10] 这段原文是《如何做出杰出的工作》一文的初稿。我一写完就意识到这是一个比超线性回报更重要的主题，所以我暂停了当前的文章，将这一段扩展成独立的一篇。

paragraphs.original: Practically nothing remains of the original version, because after I finished "How to Do Great Work" I rewrote it based on that.[11] Before the Industrial Revolution, people who got rich usually did it like emperors: capturing some resource made them more powerful and enabled them to capture more.
paragraphs.translated: 原来的版本几乎没有什么保留，因为在完成《如何做出伟大的工作》之后，我根据那本书的内容重新写了它。在工业革命之前，那些变得富有的人通常像皇帝一样：控制某种资源使他们更强大，并使他们能够控制更多的资源。

paragraphs.original: Now it can be done like a scientist, by discovering or building something uniquely valuable. Most people who get rich use a mix of the old and the new ways, but in the most advanced economies the ratio has shifted dramatically toward discovery just in the last half century.[12] It's not surprising that conventional-minded people would dislike inequality if independent-mindedness is one of the biggest drivers of it.
paragraphs.translated: 现在，这可以像科学家那样去做，通过发现或创造某种独特而有价值的事物。大多数致富的人使用了新旧方式的结合，但在最发达的经济体中，这一比例在过去半个世纪里已显著转向发现。[12] 如果独立思考是推动不平等的一个主要因素，那么传统思维的人不喜欢不平等也就不足为奇了。

paragraphs.original: But it's not simply that they don't want anyone to have what they can't. The conventional-minded literally can't imagine what it's like to have novel ideas. So the whole phenomenon of great variation in performance seems unnatural to them, and when they encounter it they assume it must be due to cheating or to some malign external influence.Thanks to Trevor Blackwell, Patrick Collison, Tyler Cowen, Jessica Livingston, Harj Taggar, and Garry Tan for reading drafts of this.
paragraphs.translated: 但这不仅仅是他们不想让别人拥有他们所没有的东西。传统思维的人根本无法想象拥有新颖想法是什么样的感受。所以，绩效的巨大差异对他们来说似乎很不自然，当他们遇到这种情况时，就认为这一定是由于作弊或某种恶意的外部影响所致。感谢 Trevor Blackwell、Patrick Collison、Tyler Cowen、Jessica Livingston、Harj Taggar 和 Garry Tan 阅读本文的草稿。
